UT done again , below UT cases executed : 

•	Various error case handling wrt mgmt vrf for "snmpagentaddress add -p -v "
a. Error case validation for invalid ip
root@sonic:~# sudo config snmpagentaddress add 260.59.133.20 -p 161 -v mgmt
Invalid IP address
root@sonic:~#
b. Error case when vrf is not provided for "snmpagentaddress add -p -v "
root@sonic:~# sudo config snmpagentaddress add 10.59.133.20 -p 161
ManagementVRF is Enabled. Provide vrf.
root@sonic:~#
c. Error case when a different ip is used for "snmpagentaddress add -p -v "
root@sonic:~# sudo config snmpagentaddress add 10.59.143.100 -p 161 -v mgmt
IP addfress is not available
root@sonic:~#
d. If ip and port exists throw a msg notifying the same
root@sonic:~# sudo config snmpagentaddress add 10.59.143.94 -p 161 -v mgmt
entry with 10.59.143.94:161 already exists
root@sonic:~#
•	Config passing without error
root@sonic:~# sudo config snmpagentaddress add 10.59.143.94 -p 161 -v mgmt
root@sonic:~#
root@sonic:~# show snmpagentaddress
ListenIP        ListenPort  ListenVrf
------------  ------------  -----------
10.59.143.94           161  mgmt
root@sonic:~#
root@sonic:~# sudo config snmpagentaddress del 10.59.143.94 -p 161 -v mgmt
root@sonic:~#
root@sonic:~# show snmpagentaddress
ListenIP    ListenPort    ListenVrf
----------  ------------  -----------
root@sonic:~#
•	Testing show cmd
root@sonic:~# show mgmt routes

Routes in Management VRF Routing Table:
default via 10.59.128.1 dev eth0
broadcast 10.59.128.0 dev eth0 proto kernel scope link src 10.59.143.94
10.59.128.0/20 dev eth0 proto kernel scope link src 10.59.143.94
local 10.59.143.94 dev eth0 proto kernel scope host src 10.59.143.94
broadcast 10.59.143.255 dev eth0 proto kernel scope link src 10.59.143.94
broadcast 127.0.0.0 dev lo-m proto kernel scope link src 127.0.0.1
127.0.0.0/16 dev lo-m proto kernel scope link src 127.0.0.1
local 127.0.0.1 dev lo-m proto kernel scope host src 127.0.0.1
broadcast 127.0.255.255 dev lo-m proto kernel scope link src 127.0.0.1
root@sonic:~#
•	Test for default kernal route via eth0 not being shown
root@sonic:~# sudo cat /proc/net/route | grep eth
eth0    00000000        01803B0A        0003    0       0       202     00000000        0       0       0                                                    
eth0    00803B0A        00000000        0001    0       0       202     00F0FFFF        0       0       0                                                    
root@sonic:~#
root@sonic:~#
root@sonic:~# sudo config vrf add mgmt
root@sonic:~#
root@sonic:~# sudo cat /proc/net/route | grep eth
root@sonic:~#

> @jleveque, @lguohan want some input from you here:
> 
> 1. Console switch feature is not a containerized feature. Do you want to see the configuration be included in feature table or Jing's approach is fine? Add the control to feature table will cause some change in feature table dependent code.
> 2. I think the current naming convention is use 'enabled' and 'disabled' to mark a state. (instead of using 'enable', disable').

Great ask, I saw we have a FEATURE table already a few days ago and I am entangled too on if use it or follow the HLD. Seems like the FEATURE table have some options for service/container only and most features are not able to configure by minigraph.

For the naming convention, we really need that. I try search our doc: https://github.com/Azure/sonic-utilities/blob/master/doc/Command-Reference.md and we have both {enable/disable} {enabled/disabled} documented, it would be never late to align them earlier.

> @jleveque, @lguohan want some input from you here:
> 
> 1. Console switch feature is not a containerized feature. Do you want to see the configuration be included in feature table or Jing's approach is fine? Add the control to feature table will cause some change in feature table dependent code.

Currently, all entries in the FEATURE table are services which manage a container. I'm not sure if want to extend that to include this "feature". @lguohan to comment.

> 2. I think the current naming convention is use 'enabled' and 'disabled' to mark a state. (instead of using 'enable', disable').

With regards to the CLI as it currently stands, `config console enable/disable` is acceptable. It might not align exactly with the "config feature ..." commands (e.g., `config feature state snmp enabled`), however, so we might want to standardize this convention across the entire CLI.

> > @jleveque, @lguohan want some input from you here:
> > 
> > 1. Console switch feature is not a containerized feature. Do you want to see the configuration be included in feature table or Jing's approach is fine? Add the control to feature table will cause some change in feature table dependent code.
> 
> Currently, all entries in the FEATURE table are services which manage a container. I'm not sure if want to extend that to include this "feature". @lguohan to comment.

Yes, actually this is a simply binary switch for console CLI, its quite different with a service since it can't 'restart' or 'auto-start'. But the FEATURE table is appropriate from the semantic aspect. Looking forward to your comments @lguohan

I have updated the PR with sonic-utilities test cases for the newly added resources.

> i am wondering if there is no data in the db, what is the output, will the command throw exception?

When no data on CONFIG_DB, crm show threshold CLI command will not have these resources listed.
When no data on COUNTERS_DB, crm show resources CLI command will not have these resources, instead will print

`CRM counters are not ready. They would be populated after the polling interval.`

No exception will be observed on both cases.

```
root@sonic:/home/admin# crm show thresholds all

Resource Name         Threshold Type      Low Threshold    High Threshold
--------------------  ----------------  ---------------  ----------------
ipv4_route            percentage                     70                85
ipv6_route            percentage                     70                85
ipv4_nexthop          percentage                     70                85
ipv6_nexthop          percentage                     70                85

ipv6_neighbor         percentage                     70                85

nexthop_group         percentage                     70                85

---------------  ----------------  ---------------  ----------------

---------------  ----------------  ---------------  ----------------

--------------------  ------------  -----------------

I believe you need to change the line

```
sku_create_script = os.path.join(scripts_path, "sonic_sku_create.py")
```

to

```
sku_create_script = "sonic_sku_create.py"
```

Because scripts_path is added to PATH in the `setup_class` method.

can you run with "sudo" option. 

What command are you using?

I just tried building the sonic utilities python wheel package. Something like “make target/python-wheels/sonic-utilities-xx”(the full path name of the package).
The unit test script will be executed during compiling.
We don’t use “sudo” when compiling the code.

"sudo" is required to run the 'pfcwd config' tests. Id suggest to add a sudo check in the test script and skip if not root.

```
if os.geteuid() != 0:
     pytest.skip("need sudo access")
```

I think to skip it if it's not prilivege user is a work around for now. But I think it's better to support testing it without "sudo".
Probably you can refer how unit test is execucted on "config" command?

We should not add any checks to skip 'root' privilege in CLI code, since any user can simulate a test environment on a production switch and bypass the 'root' privilege to make config changes. I'm open for any other suggestions.
sounds reasonable...
Is it possible to use something like `fakeroot` during the compiling in order to simulate a root user?

> Is it possible to use something like `fakeroot` during the compiling in order to simulate a root user?

@jleveque and @lguohan

I realized that, I was adding below line on teardown() of my test class, which makes console_test fail. Resolve it.

  os.environ["PATH"] = os.pathsep.join(os.environ["PATH"].split(os.pathsep)[:-1])

> I realized that, I was adding below line on teardown() of my test class, which makes console_test fail. Resolve it.
> 
> os.environ["PATH"] = os.pathsep.join(os.environ["PATH"].split(os.pathsep)[:-1])

Aha. Yes, I found and fixed other tests recently which were doing the same thing in the teardown function but not appending to the PATH in the setup function, thus breaking the PATH. 👍

@jleveque 
This PR adds only new tests, not much change in Dev Code, it will be great if we can review and merge this one. Because for any future PR we want these config breakout tests to execute. Thx.
